French--Armies -of.---the/ Iiorth and 1!or th-3ast,ia$ d- ar "General,I have the honour to acknowledge receipt of your letter lio. 25250, dated the 27th February 1917.:. I have b Pen. engc-ged; during the last few days in studying the possibilities arising out of the enemy1 s withdrawal on my Fifth Army front combined with the indications that he may intend to fall bach to thf. "Hindenburg linc"*I have delayed antwering your, letter until I had . completed this study and I now forward a p.'.per embodying my 'views on tne general situation likely to be created by such a withdrawal, and its possible effect on the British Armiee in particular. This p? per I have forwarded to General Robertson for theconsidera-tion of the British V/ar Cabinet. . -For- the reasons e-rolained in.'it I consiu or it necessary to take certain precautions at once on the front of my Second Army and to make immediate pre-parotions for a rapid transfer of more considerable forces from my Fifth Army to the north, if the situation should require it. . .-;Although it is not yet certain that the enemy intends to withdraw to the Hindenburg line he has already gone baok so far on the front of General Gough1s Army, and there is so little, room for doubt that he intends to retire still further there, that the plans I had made for an attack on that front, in combination v/ith the general scheme as already arranged, are no longer applicable. .-.It appears that General Gough is now opposed only . by rearguards, working on a carefully organised and fully, prepared scheme of retirement. Consequently, to continue offensive operations now, on a large scale, in that area would merely be. to conform with the enemy's plans.and to use up forces which may presently be very urgently re-quired elsewhere.An immediate alteration in the plan of offencepreviously arranged is therefore necessitated so far as myFifth ^rmy is concerned..I am however considering the possibility of local operations in the near future, v/ith limited forces, design-ed to add to the difficulties of the enemy's retirement from the B;.P.;Uivi3 - MONCHY-au-BOIS line and to enable me to gain the observation over the country to the north of that line.I will inform you in due course of the results af ny investigation into this question.I see no reason at present to make any serious alteration in the original plans for an attack by my Third arid First ...rmies, though some modifications in the details of this attack may be required. I have arranged to spend the next three days in an examination of the problem on the ground, and v/ill inform you of the re suit a of. this as soon as possible.An isolated attack by these two armies, with the forces available, could, however, have no more than a local effect, and the action to be takon eventually on their front must depend on the general plan. while awaiting information from you, therefore, as to what alterations you may consider necessary in the original plan of offensive on the French front, and as to how this offensive can be most effectively supported by the action of my First and Third Armies, I will push on as rapidly as possible with my preparations on the ARRAS - VUG" Ridge front. Under the altered conditions it is, of course, doubtful whether CAH3RAI will prove to be a feasible objoctive for my armies. It is also becoming very doubtful/ owing to numerous causes of delay beyond my control of which you :\re aware^ how far preparations on my First and Third Army fronts can be com-pletod by thp 8th April. At present I can see little hope of their completion by that date.As regards transportation :-I note with regret that you do not find it possible to meet my requirements. In the circumstances I have no option but to do the best I can with the moans provided.I do not propose to enter into a comparison between the needs of the French and British Armies. Even if there be an appreciable difference between them, which is not borne out by such information as is open to me, compari-sons at this stage of the campaign can serve no useful purpose. In such matters there have always been differencesof of opinion in different countries..As regards the last sentence of the second para-graph of your letter, dealing with this subject (of transportation) I understand that the arrangements for transport beyond the line LILLE -.liAUBEUGE was referred by the Committee held at CALAIS on the 27th ultimo to a meeting in PARIS to be held'yesterday with a view to a subsequent conference with the Belgians.-.As regards the composition of the proposed British Mission et your Headquarters, I have been instructed to submit the names of the officers I proposed to select to the British War Office in the first instance. On the general question of this Mission I would point out that th proposal has, so far, been discussed between us very brief and generally* Before such a Mission is formed I consider it essential that the duties and responsibilities to be allotted to it should be clearly defined in writing and I should be glad to have a statement of your views on these points e.So far as I am personally concerned, my relations with General des Vallieres, the head of the Erench Mission at my Headquarters, have always been most cordial and satisfactory, and I am far from being convinced that any advantage will be gained by duplicating the existing ar r an g em en t s c-Yours very truly,(Signed)* D* HAIG*Eield Marshall
